collaboration/faq.title: Collaboration FAQ
collaboration/faq.description: Source of truth: Lexical State, Yjs and App's DB

collaboration/react.title: React
collaboration/react.description: Lexical provides LexicalCollaborationPlugin and useCollaborationContext hook within @lexical/react to accelerate creation of the collaborative React backed editors.

concepts/commands.title: Commands
concepts/commands.description: Commands are a very powerful feature of Lexical that lets you register listeners for events like KEYENTERCOMMAND or KEYTABCOMMAND and contextually react to them wherever & however you'd like.

concepts/dom-events.title: Working with DOM Events
concepts/dom-events.description: Sometimes, when working with Lexical, it might be necessary or useful for you to attach a DOM Event Listener to the underlying DOM nodes that Lexical controls. For instance, you might want to to show a popover when a user mouses over a specific node or open a modal when they click on a node. Either of these use cases (and many others) can be accomplished via native DOM Event Listeners. There are 3 main ways that you can listen for DOM Events on nodes controlled by Lexical:

concepts/history.title: useHistory
concepts/history.description: Lexical's useHistory adds support for Undo and Redo. Part of undo and redo requires supporting coalescing of certain dynamic operations such as continuous typing. The below provides background information regarding the continuous typing undo coalescing feature.

concepts/listeners.title: Listeners
concepts/listeners.description: Listeners are a mechanism that lets the Editor instance inform the user when a certain operation has occured. All listeners follow a reactive pattern where you can do an operation upon something happening in the future. All listeners also return a function that easily allows for the

concepts/node-replacement.title: Node Overrides
concepts/node-replacement.description: Some of the most commonly used Lexical Nodes are owned and maintained by the core library. For example, ParagraphNode, HeadingNode, QuoteNode, List(Item)Node etc - these are all provided by Lexical packages, which provides an easier out-of-the-box experience for some editor features, but makes it difficult to override their behavior. For instance, if you wanted to change the behavior of ListNode, you would typically extend the class and override the methods. However, how would you tell Lexical to use your ListNode subclass in the ListPlugin instead of using the core ListNode? That's where Node Overrides can help.

concepts/serialization.title: Serialization & Deserialization
concepts/serialization.description: Internally, Lexical maintains the state of a given editor in memory, updating it in response to user inputs. Sometimes, it's useful to convert this state into a serialized format in order to transfer it between editors or store it for retrieval at some later time. In order to make this process easier, Lexical provides some APIs that allow Nodes to specify how they should be represented in common serialized formats.

concepts/transforms.title: Node Transforms
concepts/transforms.description: Transforms are the most efficient mechanism to respond to changes to the EditorState.

design.title: Lexical's Design
design.description: Note: this document is still a work-in-progress and things are likely still in flux.

faq.title: FAQ
faq.description: Why does Lexical use the $ prefix in the name of many of the functions?

getting-started/creating-plugin.title: Creating a Plugin
getting-started/creating-plugin.description: This page covers Lexical plugin creation, independently of any framework or library. For those not yet familiar with Lexical it's advisable to check out the Quick Start (Vanilla JS) page.

getting-started/quick-start.title: Quick Start (Vanilla JS)
getting-started/quick-start.description: This section covers how to use Lexical, independently of any framework or library. For those intending to use Lexical in their React applications,

getting-started/supported-browsers.title: Supported Browsers
getting-started/supported-browsers.description: Note: Lexical does not support Internet Explorer or legacy versions of Edge.

getting-started/theming.title: Theming
getting-started/theming.description: Lexical tries to make theming straight-forward, by providing a way of passing a customizable theming object that maps CSS class names to the editor on creation. Here's an example of a plain-text theme:

intro.title: Introduction
intro.description: Lexical is an extensible JavaScript web text-editor framework with an emphasis on reliability, accessibility, and performance. Lexical aims to provide a best-in-class developer experience, so you can easily prototype and build features with confidence. Combined with a highly extensible architecture, Lexical allows developers to create unique text editing experiences that scale in size and functionality.

maintainers-guide.title: Maintainers' Guide
maintainers-guide.description: This is the grimoire of arcane knowledge covering the overall organization

packages/lexical-eslint-plugin.title: @lexical/eslint-plugin
packages/lexical-eslint-plugin.description: This ESLint plugin enforces the Lexical $function convention.

packages/lexical-plain-text.title: @lexical/plain-text
packages/lexical-plain-text.description: This package provides a starting point for Lexical users by registering listeners for a set of basic commands that cover simple text-editing behavior such as entering text, deleting characters, copy + paste, or changing the selection with arrow keys.

packages/lexical-react.title: @lexical/react
packages/lexical-react.description: This package provides a set of components and hooks for Lexical that allow for text editing in React applications.

packages/lexical-rich-text.title: @lexical/rich-text
packages/lexical-rich-text.description: This package provides a starting point for Lexical users by registering listeners for a set of basic commands that cover simple text-editing behavior such as entering text, deleting characters, copy + paste, or changing the selection with arrow keys. It also provides default behavior for rich text features, such as headings, formatted, text and blockquotes.

react/create_plugin.title: Creating a React Plugin
react/create_plugin.description: In addition to using the Lexical React plugins offered by the core library, you can make your own plugins to extend or alter Lexical's functionality to suit your own use cases.

react/faq.title: React FAQ
react/faq.description: My app does not work in dev when using StrictMode, help!?

react/index.title: Lexical API
react/index.description: To make it easier for React users to implement rich-text editors, Lexical exposes a set of abstractions that aim to cover a wide range of use cases out-of-the-box.

react/plugins.title: Lexical Plugins
react/plugins.description: React-based plugins are using Lexical editor instance from `` context:

testing.title: Testing
testing.description: Lexical relies on tests to ensure that changes don't break anything, using a mix of unit and end-to-end tests.
